comment._content: www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=keep%20sketch - "Another way of telling some one to look out, "keep sketch" is a phrase popular in the East Coast of Ireland."

comment._content: maps.google.com/maps?q=Harcourt+Street,+Dublin,+Ireland&a... Street view - lots of changes

comment.author: 79549245@N06
79549245@N06
comment._content:
1931 has a Monday 13th July
as has 1936 and 1942 next one is 1953 so one of the previous 3 I think.

Also  1931 is too early for the Z 4229 reg so take your pick between 1936 and 1942

I pick 1936 as if it was 1942 there would be less cars and some signs of the "Emergency"

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Hold That 1936 Prediction it could just be 1931?? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Skin_Game_(1931_film) The Skin Game is a 1931 film by Alfred Hitchcock, based on a play by John Galsworthy and produced by British International Pictures (BIP). The story revolves around two rival families, the Hillcrists and the Hornblowers, and the disastrous results of the feud between them. Release dates26 February 1931 UK release

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Carol what does it say on the top of the Charlemont Street, street sign?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Looks like Sr. - presumably short for Sráid. And then looks like maybe Acad with the dot/buailte over the d, so that'd be Acadh? All together Sráid Acadh...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: "keeping sketch" - have not hear that one since I was a young lad back in the early 70's. The guy passing by on the bicycle appears to be looking in their direction and likely aware those two little chisseleurs are up to no good.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Sometime in 1931, I'd go for that as well.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Ah Chisellers! Haven't heard that one in ages - now adding as a tag...

Of course it may confuse people looking for workmen with chisels, but what the hell, it's nearly Christmas - let's go mad altogether!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Thanks Carol. It's an auld Dublin term for the little ones (meaning young children). You can still hear the term being used, but mainly by older people. Stuart.

comment.author: 45618415@N05
comment._content: Lovely picture of a junction I used to walk through daily.

comment.author: 45618415@N05
comment._content: Re: the translation of Charlemont Street, this page is interesting: www.photopol.com/signs/sraidbac/dubstreet.html It gives a number of options for the translation of Charelemont Road (on the Northside). E Kramm was, presumably, a member of the Dublin Jewish community, many of whom lived in that neighbourhood. No Kramms listed in the 1911 census, but several listed on www.irishjewishroots.com/
